children.title: CRC and Quality of Education
children.description: The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child gives us teachers some marvellous advice on the sortof education we must provide to children. The emphasis here is on qualityof education. We hope that you find this module inspiring and that in helps you develop your own classroom teaching style.

children.title: The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)
children.author: Aflatoun

children.title: Take a quiz part 1
children.author: Aflatoun
children.description:
How the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC) wants to help us become better teachers.

By studying this module you will find out more about the advice the United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child gives to teachers. Much of this advice is contained in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC). We want you to read an edited version of that. We also invite you to listen to part of an interview with Professor Jaap Doek in which he talks about the UNCRC. And finally we offer you part of an article by Mary Joy Pigozzi of UNICEF, New York, explaining in more detail the sort of education that will best help children.

Part One
Read the shortened version of the UNCRC and then answer these questions.  <zip||metadata> None

questions.question: Which two articles directly address the question of children’s education?
Article 29 talks about the aims of education. It says education should help children to use and develop their;

children.title: Take a quiz part 2
children.author: Aflatoun
children.description:
Part Two
Now please listen to the interview with Professor Doek as he explains what the UNCRC has to say on the provision of education and the aims of education at Articles 28 and 29.  <zip||metadata> None

questions.question: Professor Doek begins by mentioning two positions he has held. What are they?
questions.correct_answer: Chair Person of the Board of Aflatoun and Chair Person of the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child.
all_answers: Chair Person of the Board of Aflatoun and Chair Person of the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child.
Chair Person of the Board of Amnesty International and Secretary of the UN Committee on Climate Change.
Treasurer of Barcelona Football Club and Chair Person of UNICEF.

questions.question: Article 28 states that primary education should be free. Professor Doek talks about a challenge that many countries face – parents having to pay additional costs for their children’s education. What examples does he give of these additional costs?

Professor Doek says that *quality of education* refers to more than just reading and writing. Article 29 spells out what is expected from schools in terms of providing children with opportunities to develop their skills and talents. He then explains the role of teachers.

Professor Doek refers to another document, issued by the Committee on the Rights of the Child in 2001. He recommends that teachers read this document if they want to better understand what Article 29 expects of them. What is the name of this document?

children.title: What the UNCRC defines as good education for children
children.author: Aflatoun

children.title: Take a quiz part 3
children.author: Aflatoun

all_answers: Demonstrating respect for others and how to resolve conflict.

questions.question: Mary Joy talks about the processes of education i.e. *how* we teach children. She goes on to describe the sort of learning environment that teachers should provide. She argues that without such a learning environment children will not develop;
questions.correct_answer: The self-esteem that is essential for decision-making throughout life
all_answers: The strength to be good at sports
The self-esteem that is essential for decision-making throughout life

children.title: Teacher Talking Time versus Student Talking Time
children.description: The biggest focus of any Aflatoun teacher-training workshop is naturally on practice teaching. Perhaps you remember these sessions? Teachers are given lesson plans from the Aflatoun books and asked to present a mock lesson. The other participants then critique their performance using a set list of questions. One ofthe aims of those micro-teaching  sessions is to help teachers use a variety of teaching methods, beyond simply lecturing. In this module we look more closely at one aspect of classroom teaching i.e. the ratio of Teacher Talking Time versus Student Talking Time as this is very often a reliable way of measuring  the  extent  to  which students are  actively engaged  in  their  own learning. We hope that you enjoy this module, that it helps refresh your memory, provides you with a fuller  understanding of this  aspect of active-learning  and maybe  even inspires you with some  new ideas.

children.title: Brainstorming
children.description: In an Aflatoun teacher-training workshop  we normally  look at Brainstorming on the first day. Brainstorming is a very simple method on the face of it, and yet many of us teachers can find it a little bit challenging at first because it requires us to do many things that we might not be used to e.g. letting children talk in an unregulated way, not correcting their answers initially etc. We hope that you enjoy this module, that it helps refresh your memory, provides you with a fuller understanding of this aspect of active-learning and maybe even inspires you with some new ideas.

children.title: Interview with April Coetzee of Warchild Holland
children.author: Aflatoun

children.title: Take a quiz part 1
children.author: Aflatoun
children.description:
Part 1
Listen to this interview with April Coetzee, Senior Educational Adviser at War Child Holland. She’s talking about brainstorming. Then answer the following questions.  <zip||metadata> None

questions.question: The interviewer asks April why she thinks children develop a fear of giving the wrong answer to questions. Which of the following does April NOT give as a reason?
questions.correct_answer: Children worry that if they think too hard they will get a sore head.
all_answers: Children want to please the teacher so are scared if they think they might be giving the wrong answer.
In some traditions, teachers believe that a question always has one right and one wrong answer, but actually there are often many different possible answers in between.
Children worry that if they think too hard they will get a sore head.

questions.question:
The interviewer asks April how this effects children as they grow up. Listen to her answer and then look at the following statements and say if they are true are false.

April thinks that education is about more than just getting a certificate and is about more than being able to pass exams.
If you are educated in a culture that makes you scared to fail, this prevents you from learning from failure (learning from your mistakes) and from trying to do things differently.

The interviewer asks April how brainstorming contrasts with rote-learning (traditional teaching).
Listen to her answer then say whether the following statements are true or false.

Children do not like listening to answers from other children
Because initially you accept all answers it allows all children to participate.
Because everybody is engaged together it often triggers children to be more involved because they feed off each other, they feed off the answers that have come from other children.

Teachers often wonder how to deal with wrong answers that children give during a brainstorming exercise. They hear that they should accept all answers from children and worry about how to deal with wrong answers. The interviewer asks April for her advice on this question. Listen to her reply and the read the following statements. According to April’s answer, are they true or false?

By the end of the brainstorming not all answers are going to be deemed to be correct.
Of course teachers have a role to correct answers that are wrong and pull out the ones that are correct.
We should understand that children shouting out the answers that they think at the beginning is just part of the process of brainstorming, it’s not the be all and end all.
When you have a good set of ideas you need to start to narrow them down and to prioritize them.
At the end of the process if there are answers that you feel are completely wrong then you should mention those and explain why you see them as wrong.

children.title: Group Work
children.description: At some of the longer Aflatoun teacher-training workshops we do a session on group work in general, and the jigsaw method in particular. If you have participated in one of those sessions this module should help you recall ideas you might have forgotten. If you haven’t been on one of those sessions, we hope this module might stimulate your curiosity about group work and maybe even inspire you with some ideas.

children.title: Take a quiz part 1
children.author: Aflatoun
children.description:
Part One
Watch the Jigsaw Method animation and answer the following questions.  <zip||metadata> None

questions.question: The jigsaw method can be used as an alternative to what?
questions.correct_answer: Reading out a large piece of text or having your students read it.
all_answers: Reading out a large piece of text or having your students read it.

questions.question: What role do children play in a jigsaw exercise?
What do children typically have to do at the end of a jigsaw exercise?
For a team to succeed, what does each of its members need to do?
What happens if one child doesn’t try hard?
all_answers: The rest of the team succeeds anyway.
That child still does well because the rest of team help her.

questions.question: When children are working together for five minutes to read and learn their piece of text, what should they do?
questions.correct_answer: Ask each other questions and help each other to learn their piece of text.
all_answers: Ask each other questions and help each other to learn their piece of text.
Work in silence and avoid talking.
Refuse to answer questions from another child. Answering will only make that child lazy.

children.title: Take a quiz part 2
children.author: Aflatoun
children.description:
Part Two
Now listen to the audio file. Paul from Aflatoun is interviewing James Lawrie of Save the Children UK on the subject of structured group work in general.  <zip||metadata> None

questions.question:
Paul starts by asking James what the role of the teacher is in a structured group work exercise.
What is the first word James uses to describe the teacher’s role?
James says there are various things teachers can do. Which of the following examples does he NOT give?
questions.correct_answer: Bring the students drinks and snacks.
all_answers: Delegate to group members many of the tasks that he or she would ordinarily do.
Keep the group on task ensuring good social relationships.
Bring the students drinks and snacks.
Summarize what the whole class has learned at the end.

questions.question: James and Paul discuss how often teachers find it difficult to step back and let children get on with it in group work. James says that this can ‘go against the DNA of a teacher’ as teachers feel the need to be in control. His advice is that teachers don’t always need to lead, they need to;
all_answers: Ask the children to be quiet so they can lecture

questions.question: What happens if the teacher sets up the activity well?
questions.correct_answer: She keeps control over the class.
all_answers: She can leave the room and enjoy a cup of tea.
She can have a quick sleep.
She keeps control over the class.

questions.question: What advice does James offer to teachers who might be curious about trying structured group work but feels a bit nervous?
questions.correct_answer: Observe a colleague doing good group work.
all_answers: Observe a colleague doing good group work.
Go the library and get a book on the theory of group work.

children.title: Take a quiz part 3

questions.question: What do you need to have before starting a group session?
all_answers: A quiet classroom with nobody talking

questions.question: What should you allow pupils to do before you start?
all_answers: Memorize answers from the back of the book

questions.question: What should you try and achieve in the final session?
all_answers: A good, clear lecture telling students what they did wrong

children.title: Training Manual

children.description: The Training Manual seeks to familiarize the reader not only with the core themes of Aflatoun's educational materials, but also with Aflatoun's preferred child-centered pedagogical approach.
